title: 113_s884
content: The Act titled "Deter Cyber Theft Act" addresses foreign economic or industrial espionage in cyberspace. The "Deter Cyber Theft Act" requires the Director of National Intelligence to submit an annual report on foreign economic and industrial espionage in cyberspace, identifying countries engaged in espionage targeting US trade secrets. The "Deter Cyber Theft Act" mandates an annual report on foreign economic and industrial espionage in cyberspace, focusing on countries targeting US trade secrets and proprietary information. This includes technologies or information developed by US persons that are subject to economic espionage, as well as articles produced using appropriated technologies. The "Deter Cyber Theft Act" requires an annual report on foreign economic and industrial espionage in cyberspace, focusing on countries targeting US trade secrets and proprietary information. The report includes details on technologies or information developed by US persons subject to economic espionage, services provided using such technologies, and foreign entities engaging in economic or industrial espionage. The "Deter Cyber Theft Act" mandates an annual report on foreign countries engaging in economic or industrial espionage in cyberspace. The report details actions taken to decrease espionage and progress made in reducing it. The Director identifies foreign countries involved in economic or industrial espionage targeting US trade secrets. The "Deter Cyber Theft Act" requires an annual report on foreign countries involved in economic or industrial espionage in cyberspace. The President prioritizes the collection and analysis of information on countries engaging in such espionage. The intelligence community must collect and analyze information to identify specific articles, services, and entities. Reports must be submitted in unclassified form with a possible classified annex. The President must direct Customs and Border Protection to exclude certain articles from entry into the US for intellectual property rights enforcement within 120 days of each report submission. The intelligence community must collect and analyze information to identify specific articles, services, and entities for enforcement of intellectual property rights or to protect the Department of Defense supply chain. An article described is one identified under subsection (a)(1)(A)(iv), produced or exported by a government-owned entity from a priority foreign country, or produced by an entity using technologies identified under subsection (a)(1)(A)(iii). The section outlines the enforcement of intellectual property rights and protection of the Department of Defense supply chain. It specifies that the regulations should align with international agreements and provides definitions for "appropriate congressional committees." The curr_chunk defines "cyberspace" as the network of information technology infrastructures including the Internet, and "economic or industrial espionage" as stealing trade secrets without authorization. The curr_chunk discusses the unauthorized actions related to trade secrets or proprietary information, including copying, transmitting, and possessing stolen information. The term "intelligence community" is also defined. The curr_chunk defines terms related to trade secrets and proprietary information, including "own," "person," and "proprietary information" which encompasses various valuable business data. The curr_chunk defines terms related to trade secrets and proprietary information, including "technology," "trade secret," and "United States person." These terms are crucial for understanding the protection of confidential information. The curr_chunk specifies that a "United States person" refers to a citizen or permanent resident of the United States, or an entity organized under U.S. laws.
